Something that helps kids a ton is to give them ways to think about the world and themselves.

At A+UP, we teach kids the concept, "yet."

It lets us look them in the eyes and say,
"Yes. That isn't your best work..."
"Yes. You didn't hit your goal..."

"..., yet."

That simple turn of phrase tells them to keep it up.

They're not there, yet.

And that's okay. They need to see their vision for their future and know that they are works-in-progress.

Just like us.

Why is A+UP's mascot a phoenix?

The phoenix is a mythical bird from ancient legend. It would fly for hundreds of years before landing and bursting into flames. From those ashes, the phoenix is reborn to start a new, long life.

Middle school is where a lot of kids leave behind their old selves and become young adults. Like the phoenix, our middle schoolers make this change by choice, knowing that they need to leave their old ways behind and start new ones.

At A+UP we work with students on their ownership. They understand that they need to develop self-control in order to manage their habits and behaviors into ones that will help them become who THEY want to be.

A+UP faculty work side-by-side with our scholars and their families, helping them to find and develop their voice. We love watching our scholars become empowered people who will help themselves, their families, and their communities.

"Social distancing" is a terrible way to describe what we should be doing. A colleague of mine pointed out to me that the goal is "physical distancing" and that it should be described as such. When we say "social distancing" we are creating the secondary reaction in our brain that we should stay socially separated from others--no eye contact, no nods, no social interactions.

That is not who we are as people. We are social animals by nature and design. And many of us (especially kids) are having horrible and silent reactions to this social distancing that accompanies the physical distancing.

Join me in being mindful of saying "physical distancing" in your communication and remembering to smile with your eyes at your fellow humans and to stay in touch with loved ones.

#physicaldistancing
#sociallyconnected

Today is a good day to read with your kids.

Too many people think that reading aloud with kids should stop at 1st grade. Be different!

Grab your favorite book or article and read it aloud with them. Tell them what you liked about the piece and share your thinking about the piece. Try one of these starters,

"You know, I like the way the author said..."

Or...

"When I read this, I had this picture in my head that looked like... What did you see in your head?"

COVID-19 (coronavirus) is a real thing. So is the flu. To stay as safe as possible, A+UP is following the CDC guidelines for schools.
We will teach kids how to avoid getting sick:
1. Stay home if you're sick.
2. Avoid those who are sick.
3. Cover your cough and sneeze.
4. Avoid touching eyes, nose, and ears.
5. Most importantly, wash your hands for 20 seconds with soap and water. That's singing the Happy Birthday song two times!

The coronavirus and flu have an outer layer made of a lipid (a fat) that can be destroyed by soap or sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol. That kills it. So kill it with better hygiene.

We are:
1. Buying sanitizer stations for the school.
2. Teaching kids handwashing.
3. Putting handwashing posters in bathrooms.
4. Sanitizing surfaces with wipes three times a day.

Is your child a struggling reader? It may be a problem with how they were taught, not how they learn. A few decades ago, phonics fell out of favor for a variety of reasons that have nothing to do with its effectiveness. A+UP students demonstrated an average of 2.1 years of growth in reading by teaching phonics to our struggling readers-- several students gained more than four years in reading!

The tides are turning in Texas, however! We are so excited to say that a new law passed in 2019 (HB3) compels elementary schools to teach phonics in a systematic way and mandates that all elementary school principals receive instruction on phonics and learn why research definitively proves how necessary this instruction is.

Read this link to learn more, or listen to the podcast in the link.

There’s solid research showing that participating in novel experiences together and asking/answering questions of others promotes tighter bonds— so today we did just that!

post_text: A+UP University is a special place. Today, we were sharing the results of the benchmark assessment with our 8th graders. They expressed worry that they wouldn’t learn everything they needed to know by the real STAAR test. We talked about what they didn’t know yet and how they were going to learn it: ownership and empowerment. Once scholars are ready, we reach them how to resource their own learning. Today, they watched the Sugata Mitra TED talk and then set about learning and teaching one another how to do geometric dilations, something they aren’t scheduled to cover for another few weeks— and now the learning coach may not have to cover it at all! Talk about empowerment! “If children have interest, then education happens.”

I’m a principal who thinks personalized learning shouldn’t be a debate.

Aurora Institute
July 13, 2018 at 7:36 AM ·

"We’ve read articles about a debate over personalized learning centered on Silicon Valley’s “takeover” of our schools. We hear that Trojan Horse technologies are coming for our jobs. But in our school, personalized learning has meant developing lessons informed by the cultural heritage and interests of our students. It has meant providing opportunities to pursue independent projects, and differentiating curriculum, instruction, and assessment to enable our students to progress at their own pace. It has reflected a paradigm shift that is bottom-up and teacher led."

Houston METRO
October 6, 2015 at 10:27 AM ·

Yesterday, we chanced upon an intriguing group of middle school students and their teachers from A+ Unlimited Potential, a Houston area charter school. The group was taking METRORail's Redline to a wellness class at 24 Hour Fitness - Elgin & Louisiana, TX. It was so neat to learn that these kids experience an incredibly hands-on learning environment which does away with the brick and mortar walls of a traditional school. Instead, the city is their backdrop for learning. Their "classrooms" being museums, parks and universities! An impressive group, the kids were polite, inquisitive and excited about learning! #RideHoustonMETRO
